February 2, 1956
Mr. William G. Harley
Radio Station WHA
University of Wisconsin
Madison, Wisconsin
Dear Bill:
As Holt ha© summarised the Redfield tapes:
Tapes were sent to the Acceptance Subcommittee in April. In May, they were
rejected two to one. Summary of reactions: Bo, introduction too long, re¬
cording quite poor, subject matter too specialised. "les. Urbane, provoking,
thoughtful." "No. Too wordy and too dull." Letter of rejection sent to
Blakely by HJS.
June, in a confidential letter at request of Skoraia (who said "dan»it guys,
be realistic") Holt asks the subcommittee to reconsider its votes and offers
to send tapes again. One of the eonmittee asked for tapes again, and they
were sent to &LL aembers.
Reactions came in in September and October (presumably after vacations).
Again, the vote was two to on© against distribution, and the one "yes" vote
was rather reluctant in tone.
In October HJS again wrote to Blakely, giving the decision, some of the
reasons for it, and quoting a suraary of standards drawn up some time before
by the Network Committee chairman.
Most of the comments by the committeemen are in the files. Tapes of these,
plus Bryson Lectures which were distributed, ware returned to Blakely in
the fall. Latter was convinced the Acceptance Committee and/or standards
were wrong. Skornia mumbled something about "democracy," and "it all depends
on the make-up of the Committee," etc.
Conn&ttee meetings and others a mile a minute. Lots of 'em on week-ends.
Great strides. Late hours. Groggy staff. Voices raised in the backroom.
Giving Schooley copy of your interest in fulfilling your duties to BARB, as
well as of this, my reply.
